title: Business News: Hershey Lifts Its Outlook as Sales Rise
text:
The maker of Reese's peanut butter cups and Twizzlers candy said revenue increased 19% in the second quarter. Excluding recent acquisition and currency translation, Hershey said organic sales were up 14.1%.

The company joins the likes of other consumer-product companies, such as Coca-Cola Co., Unilever PLC, whose products include Ben & Jerry's ice cream and Dove shampoo, and Kimberly-Clark Corp., the maker of Huggies diapers and Cottonelle toilet paper, that have raised prices and said consumers are continuing to purchase their products.

For the three months ended July 3, Hershey reported a profit of $315 million, or $1.53 a share, up from $301.2 million, or $1.45 a share, a year earlier.

Stripping out one-time items, adjusted second-quarter earnings were $1.80 a share, above analyst expectations of $1.69, according to FactSet.

Revenue came in at $2.37 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet anticipated revenue of $2.24 billion.

For the year, Hershey now expects sales to rise 12% to 14%, up from a prior view of 10% to 12% growth, and per-share earnings to rise 9% to 12%, up from 8% to 11%.

Shares closed 2.8% higher on Thursday. As of the market close Wednesday, they were up almost 13% for the year.
